website_summaries.verdict: A lightweight and portable guide that is easy to bring into the field, although some feel that it is not as robust or user-friendly as other guides.
pros: Coverage area is from the Canadian Arctic to Mexico, and the Atlantic to the Pacific
More than 350 species, backed up by over 1,000 annotated illustrations
cons: This guide uses a lot of scientific terminology and metric measurements
may not be as user friendly as other options
Some had trouble using it to identify trees

customer_reviews.title: Awesome
customer_reviews.text: Got this for my husband for Christmas. He’s been wanting one for a long time. He absolutely LOVES this book. I decided to get this one for him vs. other ones because this is color pictures instead of B/W pictures in others I’ve found. I don’t know if that would have made a difference to him, but it did to me. It’s also a nice size, too big to fit in a pocket, but not too big to carry with you in a small backpack when hiking.
customer_reviews.author: Heidi Craig

customer_reviews.title: Good starter book
customer_reviews.text: This slim guide has drawings of the trees and leaves. It covers most of the trees found in USA. Finding a particular trees can be challenging. Also, metric sizes and lengths are given only.
customer_reviews.author: Edith Sullivan

customer_reviews.title: National Geographic tree field guide
customer_reviews.text: This was a gift for a family member who needed it in their work for identifying trees. This is one requested and it was liked and appreciated very much
customer_reviews.author: Reba

customer_reviews.title: Good, but potentially overwhelming.
customer_reviews.text: The book is extensive but sometimes inconsistent on what it shows. Most pictures will have examples of the bark or leaves, others may not. The vocabulary can be overwhelming if you are hoping to simplt pick up the book to identify a tree, you might find it necessary to read the intro and revisit it to truly be able to use the book to the best of your ability.
customer_reviews.author: Justin

customer_reviews.title: Great tree book
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this book for my fiance who runs a tree business. When we go to other regions he sees trees that we don't have here, and I thought this would help him identify them or even add to his knowledge of trees in our region. We like the book, but it would have been nice to have some color photos, not just drawings. I realize that the same tree can look very different from tree to tree, the drawings are more accurate, but it still would have been nice to have something with less imagination involved.
customer_reviews.author: K. Allen

customer_reviews.title: Good resource to have
customer_reviews.text: Great if you're out and about in the park close to your house. Very concise and easy to use. And it fits in your pocket.
customer_reviews.author: Carlos Isaac Baires Escobar

customer_reviews.title: Makes me want to run out to the forest, ...
customer_reviews.text: Makes me want to run out to the forest, lay down on my back, look up, and just absorb the beauty and silhouettes of nature's miraculous creations, the trees. Many thanks.
customer_reviews.author: Lillian Douglas

customer_reviews.title: Great Leaf Classification Book
customer_reviews.text: I am extremely happy with the quality of this product. There is imagery associated with each description. I can't wait to take it to the park. Thank you!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Best field guide ever!!
customer_reviews.text: My girlfriend bought this for me as a present. Awesome guide! Color pictures and detailed descriptions make identifying any tree a breeze!
customer_reviews.author: Colin L.

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Not at all satisfied with this publication. Nearly useless as a guide to tree identification
customer_reviews.author: tanglefoot

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: is a great companion to Trees of Western North America by Richard Spellenberg..
customer_reviews.author: Genie Currier

customer_reviews.title: Field guide illustrations to NA trees
customer_reviews.text: No photos in this guide but illustrations are often better than photos as the there no confusing background details or shadows to hide the leaves etc..Its only fault is there are are a very limited number of American trees in this guide.Nice design and handy for the pocket.
customer_reviews.author: david more

customer_reviews.title: Good book
customer_reviews.text: This book is good but photos instead of drawings would be much better for identifying trees.
customer_reviews.author: gfarbo

customer_reviews.title: Good portable guide for trees, but not shrubs
customer_reviews.text: I like this because it is compact and has a key. Keys are the fastest means to make an identification of an unknown. It is missing range maps and does not always show all the parts (flowers, fruits, bark) of the trees. That said, the illustrations are very good. Having used many guides, I have a strong preference for paintings over photos. It does not cover shrubs, which might be considered small trees. But otherwise I have found it to have good coverage of both native and introduced trees.
customer_reviews.author: Biology teacher

customer_reviews.title: easy to read
customer_reviews.text: Very informative, easy to read, great guide for the beginner :)
customer_reviews.author: Grateful Daisy

customer_reviews.title: National Geographic Field Guide to Trees of North America
customer_reviews.text: Good leaf, fruit, bud and bark pictures. Typical of NG. Uses a lot of symbols to describe a tree which means going back and forth a lot. Does not give tree height or branch geography.
customer_reviews.author: Lawrence Hanner

product_meta.title: National Geographic Field Guide to the Trees of North America: The Essential Identification Guide for Novice and Expert
